Award.AwardTitle: Commutative Algebra and Its Interactions with Algebraic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for participants, particularly junior researchers and graduate students, attending the conference "Commutative Algebra and Its Interactions with Algebraic Geometry," which will be held at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, during the period July 7-12, 2015. The conference will feature talks by a large number of researchers, representing a wide range of levels of seniority and a wide range of mathematical perspectives. The conference will foster the discovery of new connections in the theme fields and encourage new interactions and collaborations. It will provide an excellent opportunity for junior participants to meet and learn from established experts in the field, as well as to make their own work widely known. The extremely strong list of invited speakers will enable the conference to attract a large and diverse set of participants.

The conference will focus on the explosive growth of ideas connected with tight closure theory and associated asymptotic numerical invariants like Hilbert-Kunz multiplicity and F-rational signature; the analogies between notions related to tight closure theory (e.g., the theory of test ideals, various kinds of singularities defined by positive characteristic methods, and F-pure thresholds) and notions defined in algebraic geometry over the complex numbers (e.g., the theory of multiplier ideals, various kinds of singularities defined by geometric methods, and log canonical thresholds); as well as many related questions. These ideas are on the cutting edge of contemporary commutative algebra and such a large and prestigious gathering creates the potential for dramatic progress on outstanding problems and the discovery of new and illuminating research directions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award was used to support a conference in the area of the commutative algebra and algebraic geometry.  This field relates the problem of understanding the solutions of large numbers of polynomial equations in many variables both with the geometry of spaces associated with them, and with the behavior of abstract algebraic objects called commutative rings, in which one can perform algebraic operations like addition and multiplication working with elements that generalize the notion of "number."  There are finite rings, and their behavior can be used to understand phenomena over more standard examples, like the real and complex numbers.  The conference was particularly focused on disseminating information about the current state of the field to many researchers, especially graduate students, postdocs, and tenure-track assistant professors (there were seventy-eight registrants in this group) while fostering interactions among junior and senior participants.  There were approximately one hundered and fifty researchers attending.  There were twenty-nine talks given by speakers ranging from junior to senior levels. Solutions to several longstanding problems were given in the lectures, including the Eisdenbud-Goto conjecture which was an open question for over thirty years. Since the conference there have been collaborations between the junior and senior participants.   An issue of the Journal of Algebra containing papers by the speakers and some other invited participants is in progress.  The conference was regarded as very successful and the Notices of the American Mathematical Society published an article about it.
